Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation2: The task feeds directly into the next teammate’s work and delays would ripple.
Story:
I stared at my phone, reading my sister’s text: “Don’t forget, you promised to come to dinner tonight. Everyone’s excited!” I could almost hear her voice, warm and expectant. We’d been working on building a better relationship, making sure to include each other in our lives. I knew how much it meant to her that I show up, not just physically, but as someone who cared enough to make time.

But my laptop screen glared back at me, the unfinished report blinking like an accusation. The deadline was tomorrow morning, and I was already behind. If I didn’t finish tonight, my teammate would be stuck waiting, their own work delayed. I could picture the disappointment in their eyes, the subtle shift in trust. We all depended on each other to keep things moving.

My chest tightened as I weighed the expectations. My sister wanted me to be present, to show I valued our bond. My team needed me to deliver, to keep the project on track. I felt pulled in two directions, the pressure mounting as the clock ticked on.
